channel.title: Home on Rostyslav Ivanitsa
channel.description: Recent content in Home on Rostyslav Ivanitsa

item.title: Prompt engineering is dead.
item.description: A probabilistic collection leveraging Bloom Filters to store a set of 1 billion visited URLs in 18mb.

item.title: Search Engine in Rust
item.description: A search engine overview and Rust implementation, supporting free and boolean ranked queries, efficient disk and memory usage, and spelling correction.

item.title: Log-Structured Merge Tree
item.description: An LSM Tree overview and Java implementation, with a Skiplist, SStables, and background compaction from scratch.

item.title: About
item.description:
Hi there! ðŸ‘‹ Ros is here. I am a product manager located in the Bay Area. For the last decade +, I’ve been a pm at companies like Amazon, Salesforce, Sephora, and others. My focus: taking ideas from inception to scale, impacting millions. Here I share some of my learnings.

I hold an MS in Information Technology from Odesa Polytechnic University. My career spans across SaaS and Cloud services, AI/ML and Data Analytics, eCommerce and MarTech/AdTech domains. At Amazon, my team was building a B2B Marketplace enabling a bulk purchasing experience with the ease of a B2C customer. At Salesforce, Business Technology (BT) org, I’ve built SFDC CRM apps to streamline developer and admin operations, as well as workplace and employee experience. At Sephora, I lead products pertaining to data infrastructure, ML, and advanced analytics, enabling marketing automation and omnichannel personalization.

item.title: Library
item.description:
Designing Data-Intensive Applications
Excellent book about many distributed systems concepts, databases, and big data processing ideas.

Introduction to information retrieval
How search engines work, how they are built and maintained. Also covers web crawling.

AI-Powered Search
Building AI-enhanced modern search engines, covering semantic search, learn to rank, LLM summaries, etc.

Database Internals
Deep dive into database concepts that the first book only touches briefly, like data organization on disk, log-structured databases, and so on. It also covers distributed systems.
